description: From Latin tintinnābulum (“a small monastic bell”).

entries.meaning: A small clinking bell, particularly (historical) a small bell used to call monks to certain tasks.
examples: ...it is worth while to enumerate the different kinds of bells named by Hieronymus Magius in his work De Tintinnabulis:—1. Tintinnabulum, a little bell, otherwise called tinniolum, for refectory or dormitory, according to Belethus, but Durandus names squilla for the refectory...

entries.meaning: A set of bells or metal plates used as a musical instrument or as a toy.
